Posts.Title: 8 Weeks post Surgery

Posts.Content: As you asked, my opinion is this. If, when you married your wife, she was a smoker then you accepted that at the time. Obviously she still continues to smoke or has taken it up since your marriage. Now you need to quietly negotiate where she wants to smoke, where you wish her not to but not in a confrontive way. You can not now demand that she do this or that in the way that you want her to do. Maybe a solution if she agrees would be for her to do so in a certain room away from where you are and if she is smoking there you don't go in there at those times. She may agree to smoke outside as many do these days, she may not as this is her house too. You also have the choice to leave the room she is smoking in. Why do you feel that your wishes should be the priority when marriage is a joint effort of give and take? Don't demand. Phrase your sentences with I feel, when this happens, I feel and would like you to consider... etc etc She may be refusing as she feels defensive with the way you are going about it. Good luck and best wishes.

Posts.Content: You are really pushing it. Please read the rules for new posters regarding links and the reasons we have this policy. These are available at the top of each forum or in our forum policies forum. If you do not want to do the normal testing procedures and want to trust to a dog to smell your bum then go right ahead but don't ask about it here in a forum that trusts in conventional screening methods. Just decide how you want to be tested and do it then find a forum that supports how you wish to diagnose then proceed if needed.

Posts.Title: Husband, probable high PSA/wasn't

Posts.Content: ...well, that's what I recon. Hubby had a PSA test due to frequent urination. Age 49. Call from Doc's surgery says want to see him..urgent. Doc has never has used the word urgent before, even with my tests, diagnosis and treatment. Due to this I am expecting him to tell us high PSA plus or minus a UTI. Did ask hubby to ask for free PSA reading but he didn't. A DRE was not performed either, doc saw no need. I wasn't going to tell hubby till lunchtime tomorrow, a couple of hours before the appointment as he is a farmer, can take time off when needed but tomorrow arvo he is getting some stuff in the truck am and pm. Rats,, had to tell him so he could schedule the trips better. Have printed out a few reputable site's advice on high PSA's..other things it can mean as he has never believed anything I say unless it is backed up by someone else, after 21 years I am used to that. No more printed info as that is where we are at the moment. He went deeply into a black hole with my diagnosis but he did pull himself out of it a few weeks later and was so fantastic during my treatment. I, of course will be his rock if needed, just as he was mine. We now hurry up and wait, lol. Used to that..which is actually a good thing. Already know the fun of that. Will let you know when I know more and if anything eventuates from this I will be using your experiences and opinions. Hubby won't join..not his thing and I will play it anyway he wants to should further tests reveal cancer. At the moment of course and even after the appointment tomorrow we won't know much. Again, BLAAAAK! He will not handle this at all well for a while. Oh well. Hope it turns out to be infection.

Posts.Title: New to this, Recently diagnosed with Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: I also like to look at it from another angle..when we heard about others with cancer before we had it. What were our reactions? Did we want to know the nitty gritty? Did we continue with them as normal or did we back away, not sure what to do so we justified it by thinking that by saying or doing nothing at least we weren't making things worse as we just might add to their misery by talking about it? Did we step up to the plate, maintain normal contact, sit back and hope like heck there would be good news but never instigateing contact? Some people can not and do not want to confront their own mortality so they block it out until they, or someone they love faces it. They then and only then can see what needs there really are and how what they perceived to be the right thing either was, or was not right, depending on their outlook.

Posts.Content: thezac, please read the rules for new members which is at the top of all forums here http://www.cancerforums.net/announcement.php?f=56 In particular Policy for Links New members are permitted to link to their personal blog as well as links to reputable cancer sites. The links will either be allowed or disallowed at a Moderator's, Super moderator's or Administrator's discretion. All links will be checked until proven after one month's membership that the new member is legitimate. This is the only effective way to keep spammers and scammers at bay. We encourage you to use this introductory time to post messages about your own struggle with cancer (or that of a loved one), ask questions or offer advice and a link to reputable sites.

Posts.Content: I am so sorry to read about your friend, newporter. May he rest in peace. In Australia there ad campaigns to get more people screened so as to lower death rates by early detection. At the moment they are running melanoma, prostate and bowel cancer ads. Personally, I can not see any sense in not doing this. Another ad was that if you know this song that they played, you are over 40 and you should have a diabetes check up. I knew every word of it.

Posts.Title: Noticed a lump in my left breast

Posts.Content: I am going to jump in here but I can't answer the link with your cancer. As you can see in my sig I too had a nodule. Utrasound thought it was ok but only because of my previous cancer they wanted to just make sure it was. Thyroid scan, needle biopsy all good. The biopsy is painless..they numb you well and it is done under the guidance of an ultrasound. Edit..re read your post, you know this. Fine needle biopsies are next to useless for diagnosing my kind of cancer but have close to 100% success rate with thyroid. Not meaning to sound too blase but my thoughts on if I had a thyroid cancer then it was so mild compared to the one I had. I figured worst case scenario yep, cancer..have it out...do the low iodine diet (worst bit of the whole thing to my mind)..have the glow in the dark pills in hospital isolation a few days then meds the rest of my life which about a gazillion of the population are on for high or low Thyroid levels anyway.

Posts.Title: Generic Cialis?

Posts.Content: Fot 18 years my father lived, on my sister's propery in a self contained flat in another state that was built under their home (a "Queenslander") home, built on pylons with the bottom enclosed for him. For the last 5 of those years he ran her and her family ragged. It got to the stage that she could no longer lift him up from the floor after a fall. We had to make the decision that he needed 24hr care. He did NOT want this. Tried every imagined emotional blackmail and manipulation on my sister. She eventually had to place him in care. He hated it for a couple of years then told her that she had indeed done the right thing. He had 24hour care. It was so hard for both of them to accept. She was there daily for the first couple of years. I was there when I could travel the 1600 kilometers. This may have to be considered in the future for the best situation for him, and your family.

Posts.Title: Update and question about blood donation post op

Posts.Content: My 80 year old father, frail and in a nursing home was suspected of having bowel cancer after a scan. As he was of sound mind, when he said he wanted not to pursue it, did not want any treatment other than for pain, we respected his wishes. He passed away a few years ago and my sister and I are still happy that we did not push him to treatment. My advice is to tell him that cancer is suspected but can only be verified by biopsy. See if he changes his mind and if not..support his decision.

Posts.Title: Prostate MRI

Posts.Content: Fot 18 years my father lived, on my sister's propery in a self contained flat in another state that was built under their home (a "Queenslander") home, built on pylons with the bottom enclosed for him. For the last 5 of those years he ran her and her family ragged. It got to the stage that she could no longer lift him up from the floor after a fall. We had to make the decision that he needed 24hr care. He did NOT want this. Tried every imagined emotional blackmail and manipulation on my sister. She eventually had to place him in care. He hated it for a couple of years then told her that she had indeed done the right thing. He had 24hour care. It was so hard for both of them to accept. She was there daily for the first couple of years. I was there when I could travel the 1600 kilometers. This may have to be considered in the future for the best situation for him, and your family.

Posts.Title: Advice on how to tell my father he has cancer.

Posts.Content: My 80 year old father, frail and in a nursing home was suspected of having bowel cancer after a scan. As he was of sound mind, when he said he wanted not to pursue it, did not want any treatment other than for pain, we respected his wishes. He passed away a few years ago and my sister and I are still happy that we did not push him to treatment. My advice is to tell him that cancer is suspected but can only be verified by biopsy. See if he changes his mind and if not..support his decision.

Posts.Title: Two blondes walk into a hospital...

Posts.Content: here in Oz we have very venomous ones too. I was bitten by a brown but that was before cancer. My thoughts are, if I was bitten afterwards that wow, I could have been dead in an hour and may cancer would have taken longer to kill me. I guess the best thing is to ask your Doc but I don't guess there would be many relevant studies. That bite could have killed you but you are still alive.

We do our best and also weed out any who try to push any unscientifically unproved quack or anecdotal alternative treatments, people soliciting funds from our members to donate to places like go fund me, (who can tell if they are genuine or scammers and our members have enough problems of their own) ambulance chasing lawyers, those wanting us to do surveys for school or other projects like a book they are writing etc as we just try to be a support forum for patients and care givers by patients and care givers.
